projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: ‚ùÄA Treati≈øe made by Athana≈øius the great, wherin is ≈øet forth, how, and in what maner ye may v ‚Ä¢ e the P≈øalmes according to the effect of the mynde, of gladnes, or ≈øorrow accordingly, whiche P≈øalmes ye ≈øhall v≈øe for prayer, whiche for thankes geuyng, which for reher≈øall of gods wonderfull actes to the pray≈øe of his name. Al≈øo ye may ≈øee in them how God hath holpen his cho≈øen people from tyme to tyme, and neuer for≈øaken them.
div.p: THe whole Scripture vniuer≈øally, is as it were a diuine mai≈øtres, teachyng both vertue & true fayth: but the booke of P≈øalmes hath ouer and be≈øides that in a maner an expre≈ø≈øe Image of the ≈øtate and condition of ≈øoules. For as he which goeth to a king, compo≈øeth fir≈øt his behauiour, and ≈øetteth in order his wordes, lea≈øt he ≈øhould be counted ru≈øticall & rude: ≈øo this diuine booke, fir≈øt by choi≈øe of all motions, wher with the ≈øoule is affected, warneth, then frameth and in≈øtructeth by diuers formes of ≈øpeakyng, all ≈øuch as couet vertue, & de≈øyre to knowe the lyfe of the Sauiour. It is ea≈øye therefore for euerye man to fynde out in the P≈øalmes, the motion and ≈øtate of his owne ≈øoule, and by that meanes, his owne fygure and proper erudition. Moreouer, with what wordes he may plea≈øe God, and with what words he may correct him≈øelfe, and geue God thankes, lea≈øt if he ≈øpeake that thing whiche is not leafull, he fall into impietie. For not alone of deedes, but al≈øo of euery word mu≈øt we geue accoÃÑpt before the Iudge. Wherfore if thou wylt pronounce any maÃÑ happy and ble≈ø≈øed: thou ha≈øt how and wherfore, and whom thou mai≈øt call happye in the P≈øalmes, as you may ≈øee in the fyr≈øte P≈øalme, 32. P≈øalme. 41. P≈øalme, 112. P≈øalme. 119. P≈øalme, and the. 128. P≈øalme.
If thou wylte complayne of the laying awayte of the Iewes again≈øt the Sauiour, ≈øaye the ≈øecond P≈øalme.
If thyne acquaintaunce per≈øecute thee, and many ry≈øe agayn≈øte thee, thou ha≈øt the third P≈øalme.
If thou beyng troubled on this ≈øort, ha≈øt called vpon the Lord, and becau≈øe he hath heard thee, thou woulde≈øt geue hym thankes: ≈øyng the .4. P≈øalme and the .115. P≈øalme.
If thou perceiue≈øt wayte to be layde for thee of euill willers, and de≈øire≈øt that thy prayer ≈øhould be heard, ≈øyng the .5. P≈øalme.
If thou feele≈øt the threatnings of God, and therby perceiue≈øt thy ≈øelfe to be di≈ømayed, thou mai≈øt ≈øay the .6. P≈øalme, and the .37. P≈øalme.
If any con≈øult or con≈øpire again≈øt thee, as Achitophel again≈øt Dauid, and ≈øome man tell in thee, ≈øyng the .7. P≈øalme.
When thou con≈øidere≈øt the grace of our Sauiour euery where ≈øpred abroade, & mankind re≈øtored vnto health, then if thou wilt talke to the Lord, ≈øyng the .8. P≈øalme.
If againe thou wilt ≈øyng of the wondrous workes of God, geuing God thankes, thou ha≈øt the 8. P≈øalme, and the 81. P≈øalme.
If thou wilt haue thine enemy ≈øtopped and driuen backe, and neuertheles the creature to be ≈øaued, not tru≈øting in thy ≈øelfe, but in gods ≈øonne, ≈øay the, 9. P≈øalme.
If any man will make thee afrayd, thou with tru≈øt in the Lord ≈øhalt ≈øing the .10. P≈øalme
If thou ≈øee≈øt the pride and malice of many to abound, ≈øo that nothing (which is good and godly) is regarded among≈øt men, fly thou vnto the Lord, and ≈øay the .11. P≈øalme.
If the lyinges in wayte of enemies continue ≈øtil, do not forget thy ≈øelfe as though the lord ≈øet nought by thee, but call vpon the Lord, ≈øinging the .26. P≈øalme.
If thou heare any man bla≈øpheming & ≈øpeakyng ill again≈øt gods prouidence: be not thou partaker of their wickednes, but flying vnto God, ≈øay the .14. P≈øalme, and .53. P≈øalme.
If thou wilt know what ≈øort the lyfe of a Citezin of the kingdome of heauen is, ≈øyng the 15. P≈øalme.
If thou ha≈øt neede of prayer for them which with≈øtand thee and compa≈ø≈øe thy ≈øoule about ≈øyng the .17. p≈øalme, and 86. 89. and 142. P≈øalme.
If thou wilt know how Moy≈øes prayed, thou ha≈øt the .96. P≈øalme.
If thou art e≈øcaped from enemies, and deliuered from them which per≈øecute thee, ≈øyng the 18. P≈øalme.
If thou maruele≈øt at the order of thinges created, and the grace of the deuine prouidence, ≈øyng the .19. 26. 27. P≈øalmes.
If thou ≈øee≈øt any man troubled, comforte them, and praying for them, ≈øaye the wordes of the 20. P≈øalme.
If thou ≈øee≈øt thy ≈øelfe kept of the Lord, and that thou pro≈øpere≈øt, reioyce and ≈øyng the, 23. p≈øalme.
If thyne enemies ru≈øh vpon thee, lyft vp thy ≈øoule to God, and ≈øay the .25. P≈øalme, & thou ≈øhalt ≈øee them worke wickednes in vayne.

If thyne enemies per≈øeuer and continue, and with bloudy handes ≈øeeke to ≈øeduce thee or kill thee, geue not iudgement vnto man, for all humayne thynges are ≈øu≈øpect. But requyryng God to be iudge, who is the onely Iudge, ≈øay the 26. P≈øalme. and 35. 43. P≈øalme.
If thine enemies cruelly cur≈øe thee, and multiply as it were an ho≈øt with de≈øpite: feare not no more then though thou were nothyng in daunger at al, and ≈øyng the 46. P≈øalme.
If agayne they be impudent, which lye in wayte, ≈øet thou nothing by them, but ≈øyng vnto the Lord that which is in the .47. P≈øalme.
If thou wylt know how thou ought to go vnto the lord, when thou wilt geue him thanks, plainly thou ≈øhalt vnder≈øtand and ≈øee in the 48. P≈øalme.
Furthermore, when thou renue≈øt thy hou≈øe and ≈øoule, which receiueth the Lorde, and the ≈øen≈øible hou≈øe in which thou bodily dwelle≈øt: geue thankes and ≈øay the 49. and 127. p≈øalme.
If thou ≈øee thy kin≈ømen and frendes hate thee for the truth, leaue not of thy loue, neither feare ≈øuch aduer≈øaries, but thinke what is to come, and ≈øyng the 31. p≈øalme.
If thou ≈øee≈øt them that be chri≈øtened, deliuered from the corruptible birth, maruelyng at the deuine bounteou≈ønes, ≈øyng the .31. p≈øalme.
If thou wilt ≈øing with the iu≈øt men, & remembring them which liue a right, ≈øing the 33. p≈ø.
If thou ha≈øt fallen amonge≈øt enemyes, and wi≈øelye e≈øcaped them, and fledde from their ≈ønares, and therfore wilt geue thankes, cal together the meeke, & ≈øyng wyth them the .34. p≈øal
If thou ≈øee the wicked ≈øtriue to do mi≈øchiefe, thinke not that ≈øinne is naturally in them, as certayne heretykes helde an opinion, but ≈øay the 36. p≈øalme.
If thou ≈øee the euil worke vnrighteou≈ønes, and beare them≈øelues loftye again≈øt the lower ≈øort, and de≈øire≈øt to warne ≈øome therof, ≈øay the 37. p≈øalme.

If thou ha≈øte determined to take heede vnto thy ≈øelfe, and ≈øee≈øt the aduer≈øarye lying in wayte, who is mo≈øte earne≈øt agayn≈øt ≈øuche, and woulde≈øt arme thy ≈øelfe again≈øt him, ≈øyng the 39. p≈øalme.
If thou ≈øee≈øt many poore men and beggars, and woulde≈øt pitie theÃÑ, thou maie≈øt both trye them which are now pitied already, and exhort other to do the ≈øame, ≈øaying the 41. p≈øalme.

If thou ha≈øt a de≈øire toward God, and heare≈øt the enemies vpbraiding, let it not di≈ømaye thee, but vnder≈øtandyng the immortall fruite, whiche ≈øpringeth of thys de≈øire, comforte thy ≈øoule with hope towarde God, and with this relieue, and mitigate the griefes of lyfe, ≈øaying p≈øalme .42.

If thou wylt ofteÃÑ cal to remembrance the benefytes of God which he ≈øhewed to the fathers, bothe in the goyng oute of Egypte, and in the wylderne≈ø≈øe, and howe God was good to them, but they were vnthankefull: thou ha≈øt the 44. p≈øalme, and the .79. 80. 102. 106. 107. 114. p≈øalmes.

If flying vnto God thou ha≈øte e≈øcaped ≈øuche thynges as were ≈øpoken agayn≈øt thee, and woulde≈øt geue thankes vnto God, and declare his liberalitie and goodnes towardes thee, thou ha≈øt the 46. p≈øalme.
If thou ha≈øt ≈øynned, and beyng turned. falle≈øt to repentance, and woulde≈øt obteyne mercy, thou ha≈øt the wordes of confe≈ø≈øion in the 51. p≈øalme.
If thou ha≈øt ≈øuffred a fal≈øe accu≈øation before an euill king, and ≈øee≈øt the enemye to boa≈øt: go a≈øide and ≈øay the .52. p≈øalme

If any per≈øecute thee and quarell, willing to betray thee, like as the Phari≈øeis dyd Chri≈øt, and ≈øtraungers Dauid, aba≈øhe not thy ≈øelfe, but with tru≈øt in the Lord, ≈øyng the 54. p≈øalme, & the .56. p≈øalme.

If per≈øecution chaunce, and the per≈øecutor vnwares enter into the caue where thou arte hid, feare not, for thou ha≈øt in this ≈øtrayte profitable wordes, both for comfort and forremembraunce of the≈øe thinges, in the 57. p≈øalme, and a 142.

If he that lyeth in wayte of thee, haue commaunded to watch and be≈øet thy hou≈øe, & thou ha≈øt e≈øcaped, geue thankes vnto god, and in the tables of thy ≈øoule, graue the thyng, and ≈øay the 59. p≈øalme.

If the enemies which trouble thee, vpbrayde thee, and with many wordes backbyte thee which ≈øeeme to be frendes, and in the exercy≈øe of this thy cro≈ø≈øe thou art ≈øomwhat weake: thou maie≈øt call vpon the ≈øame al≈øo ≈øaying the 4. p≈øalme.

If they ≈øharpely ru≈øh vpon thee and would catche thy ≈øoule, ≈øet again≈øt them thy ≈øubiection to Godward, and be of good comfort, for the fiercer they are, the more ≈øhall they be ≈øubiect vnto God, ≈øay thou the 62. p≈øalme.

If the enemies make thee afrayd and cea≈øe not to ≈øowe deceytes, and ≈øearche alwayes again≈øt thee: although they bee neuer ≈øo many, cea≈øe not for all that, for their nets ≈øhall be lyke ≈øhaftes of little children, if thou ≈øing the 64. 68. 70. 71. p≈øalmes.

If thou a≈øke mercy of God, ≈øing the 67. p≈øalme.

If thou thinke≈øt expedient to confe≈ø≈øe thee, ≈øyng the 71. 75. 92. 105. 106. 108. 111. 118. 136. and 138. p≈øalmes.

If the enemies hold on and continue breaking in, and defiling the hou≈øe of god, and killing the ≈øainctes, and ca≈øting their bodies to the foules of the ayre, feare not theyr crueltye, but ≈øuffring with them that ≈øuffer affliction, ≈øay the .79. p≈øalme.

If thou (beyng but a meane man) peraduenture art ≈øet before thy brethren in ≈øome thing, puffe not vp thy ≈øelfe in pryde again≈øt them, but geue the prai≈øe to god, and ≈øing the 152. or the 151. p≈øalmes.
If thou wilt ≈øing particularly of the ≈øauior, thou ha≈øt of him in euery p≈øalme: but ≈øpecially in the .25. and the .110. P≈øalme
Such p≈øalmes as ≈øhewe hys lawfull generation of the father, and hys pre≈øence, is the .11. P≈øalme.

Such as preache of the diuine cro≈ø≈øe, and how much lying in wayte he receyued for vs.
and how great thinges he ≈øuffered, are the .2. p≈øalme, and the .119. p≈øalme.
Such as ≈øignifye the lyinges in wayte of the Iewes, and the malice, and Iudas I≈øcariothes betrayinges, are the .21. p≈øalme, and the .50. 72. p≈øalmes.
Such as declare his kingdome, and power to iudge, and his pre≈øence in the fle≈øhe, is the 16. p≈øalme.
For declaration of hys glorious re≈øurrection in the fle≈øhe, read the .24. & the .47. p≈øalmes.
For his a≈øcention into heauen, read the .93. p≈øalme .96. and the .98. the .99. p≈øalmes.
Which if thou read, thou may≈øt e≈øpye what benefites the Lorde be≈øtowed vpon vs by hys pa≈ø≈øion.
To him be glory for euer.

div.head: ‚ùßThe v≈øe of the re≈øt of the p≈øalmes not comprehended in the former Table of Athana≈øius.
div.p: IF thou woulde≈øt pray≈øe God, becau≈øe he hath geuen vs a good prince, which will and doth puni≈øhe the enemies of Chri≈øtes religion, v≈øe the 21. P≈øalme.
If thou be per≈øecuted without a cau≈øe, if thou woulde≈øt haue no affinitie with vice, nor with the vicious, v≈øe the .26. P≈øalme.
If thou woulde≈øt not be wicked, if not accouÃÑted as a malefactor: but woulde≈øt haue theÃÑ puni≈øhed, and thy ≈øelf and ≈øuch other godly men defended from their tiranny, v≈øe the .28. P≈øalme.
If thou ≈øee≈øt the nobilitie, the councell, the magi≈øtrates, and princes not geuen to religion, nor to the pray≈øing of God, v≈øe the .29. P≈øalme.
If thou de≈øire≈øt to be iu≈øt and vertuous, v≈øe the .33. P≈øalme.
If thou be afflicted with any ≈øickenes, and woulde≈øt fayne lyue and ≈øee good dayes and Chri≈øtes glory to be encrea≈øed, v≈øe the .39. P≈øalme.
If thou be bani≈øhed for religion, and art almo≈øt in di≈øpayre of returnyng to the country, v≈øe the .42. P≈øalme.
If thou perceyue thy ≈øelfe for≈øaken of God, and therfore per≈øecuted for religion and vertues ≈øake, v≈øe the .44. P≈øalme.
If thou woulde≈øt complayne of Doeg, of a wicked man, and woulde≈øt haue him to bee rooted out, and thy ≈øelfe to haue pro≈øperitie, v≈øe the .52. P≈øalme.
If thou woulde≈øt be deliuered from thyne enemies whiche per≈øecute thee vnto death, v≈øe the .54. P≈øalme.
If thou woulde≈øt haue the helpe of God agayn≈øt ≈øuch as per≈øecute thee without a cau≈øe, v≈øe the .59. P≈øalme.
If thou woulde≈øt prepare thy ≈øelfe to fight agayn≈øt the Idumeans, or ≈øuch lyke enemies of Chri≈øt, v≈øe the .60. P≈øalme.

If thou woulde≈øt haue Chri≈øt to come conquere and beate downe the Sirians, Idumeans, Aimnonites, Papi≈øtes, Antichri≈øtians, Nullifidians, Neutralles, and vngratious Pelagians, v≈øe the .68. P≈øalme.

If thou be per≈øwaded that Chri≈øt will come and puni≈øhe offenders, ayde the true wor≈øhippers, and poure out the dregges of wine, and the vengeaunce of his cup, on the vngodly, v≈øe the .75. P≈øalme.

If thou neyther woulde≈øt haue Idolatry, neither any lycentious lu≈øtes rayne in Chri≈øtes common wealth, thou mu≈øt geue God thankes, if thou be per≈øwaded, he both will and caÃÑ take them awaye, v≈øing the .81. P≈øalme.
If thou woulde≈øt gladly know Chri≈øtes Churche, & how that Sion ≈øignifieth it, and how that the true religion ≈øhalbe delated and ≈øpred through the whole world, v≈øe the .87. p≈øalme.
If thou goe≈øt to fight again≈øt the Idumeans, or any of Chri≈øtes enemies, whether they offend in maners, or in doctrine, and woulde≈øt de≈øire God to geue the victory, v≈øe the .108. p≈øal.
If thou woulde≈øt liue a godly life, if yu woulde≈øt repleni≈øh thy minde with godly preceptes, and therby obt ‚Ä¢ ine immortalitie, and eternall felicitie: Study diligently the .119. p≈øalme.
If thou be thru≈øt into a college, or into a pari≈øh, town or country, who≈øe inhabitours are wicked, crafty, & malicious pickequarels, woulde≈øt be deliuered froÃÑ theÃÑ, v≈øe the .120. p≈øalme.
If thou woulde≈øt haue the congregation of Chri≈øt to pro≈øper, v≈øe the .122. p≈øalme.
If thou woulde≈øt be deliuered from contempt, infamy, and the deri≈øion of the wicked, v≈øe the .123. p≈øalme.
When thou art deliuered out of pri≈øon, captiuity, or any di≈øtres, in geuyng thankes to God, v≈øe the .124. p≈øalme.
To vnder≈øtande the ≈øafety that tho≈øe are in, whiche are vnder the tuition of the Lorde, Iehoua, and how that the wicked ≈øhalbe puni≈øhed, con≈øider the .125. p≈øalme.

If thou de≈øire≈øt to knowe the felicitie that he hath whiche reuerenceth God, and lyueth godly, the traÃÑquilitie and peace of con≈øcience which he enioyeth in this life, and the vn≈øpeakable ioye in the lyfe to come, meditate diligently the .128. p≈øalme.
To vnder≈øtande howe the good and godly are defended by the ayde of the Lord, and the wicked peri≈øhe, con≈øider the .129. p≈øalme.

If thou woulde≈øt pray≈øe vnitie and concorde among brethren, v≈øe the .133. p≈øalme.
To ≈øing pray≈øes to God for his mercies, v≈øe the .134. P≈øalme.

div.head: Veni Creator.
div.p:
„Äà‚ô´„Äâ
COme holy gho≈øt eternal God, procedyng froÃÑ
„Äà‚ô´„Äâ aboue, both from the Father & the ≈øonne, the „Äà‚ô´„Äâ God of peace & loue. Vi≈øite our mindes & into vs, thy heauenly grace „Äà‚ô´„Äâ in≈øpyre: that in all truth and godlines, we may haue true de≈øyre.

lg.l: Thou art the very comforter, in all woe and di≈øtre≈ø≈øe:
The heauenly gift of God mo≈øt high, which no tonge can expre≈ø≈øe.
The fountaine and the liuely ≈øpring, of ioye cele≈øtiall:
The fyre ≈øo bright, the loue ≈øo cleare, and vnction ≈øpirituall.
Thou in thy giftes art manifold, wherby Chri≈øts church doth ≈øtand:
In faythfull hartes writing thy lawe, the fynger of Gods hand.
According to thy promi≈øe made, thou geue≈øt ≈øpeech of grace:
That through thy helpe ye prai≈øe of God, may ≈øtand in euery place.
O holy gho≈øt into our wittes, ≈øend downe thy heauenly light:
Kindle our hartes with feruent loue, to ≈øerue God day and night.
Strength and ≈øtabli≈øh all our weaknes, ≈øo feable and ≈øo frayle:
That neither fle≈øh, the world, nor deuill, agayn≈øt vs doe preuaile
Put backe our enmies far from vs, and graunt vs to obtaine:
Peace in our harts with god and maÃÑ, without grudge or di≈ødaine.
And graunt (O lord) that thou being, our leader and our guide:
We may e≈øchew the ≈ønares of ≈øinne, and from thee neuer ≈ølyde.
To vs ≈øuch plenty of thy grace, good Lord graunt we thee pray,
That thou mai≈øt be our comforter, at the la≈øt dreadfull day.
Of all ≈øtrife and di≈ø≈øention, O Lord di≈ø≈øolue the bandes:
And make the knots of peace & loue, throughout all chri≈øteÃÑ ÃÑ landes.
GrauÃÑt vs (O Lord) through thee to know, the father mo≈øt of myght:
That of his deare beloued ≈øonne, we may attayne the ≈øight.
And that with perfect fayth al≈øo, we may acknowledge thee:
The ≈øpirit of them both alway, one God in per≈øons three.
Laude and pray≈øe be to the father, and to the Sonne equall:
And to the holy ≈øpirite al≈øo, one God coeternall.
And pray we that the onely ≈øonne, vouche≈øafe his ≈øprit to ≈øend:
To all that do profe≈ø≈øe his name, vnto the worldes ende. Amen.
O Come, and let vs now reioyce, and ≈øing vnto the Lord:
And to our onely ≈øauiour, al≈øo with one accorde.
O let vs come before his face, with inwarde reuerence:
Confe≈ø≈øing all our former ≈øunnes, and that with diligence.
To thanke him for his benefites, alwaye di≈øtributyng,
Wherefore to him right ioyfully, in P≈øalmes now let vs ≈øing.
And that becau≈øe that God alone, is Lord magnificent:
And eke aboue all other gods, a kyng omnipotent.
His people doth not he for≈øake, at any time or tyde:
And in his hand are all the coa≈øtes, of al the world ≈øo wyde.
And with his louing countenaunce, he looketh euery where:
And doth behold the tops of all, the mountaines far & neere.
The ≈øea and all that is therin, are his, for he them made:
And eke his haÃÑd hath facioned, ye earth which doth not fade,
O come therfore and wor≈øhip him, and downe before him fall:
And let vs wepe before ye Lord, the which hath made vs al.
He is our God, our Lord and kyng, and we his people are:
His flocke and ≈øheepe of his pa≈øture, on whoÃÑ he taketh care.
This day if ye do heare his voyce, yet hearden not your hart:
As in the bitter murmuring, when ye were in de≈øerte.
Whiche thing was of their negligence, committed in the time,
Of trouble in the wildernes, a great and greuous crime.
Where as your fathers tempted me, and tryed euery way:
They proued me & ≈øaw my workes, what I could do or ≈øay.
The≈øe forty yeares I haue bene greued, with this generation:
And euermore I ≈øaid they e ‚Ä¢ d, in their imagination.
Wherwith their harts wer fore combred, long time and many daies:
Wherfore I know a≈ø≈øuredly, they haue not knowen my wayes.
To whom I in mine anger ≈øwore, that they ≈øhould not be ble≈øt:
Nor ≈øee my ioy cele≈øtiall, nor enter in my re≈øt.
All laud and pray≈øe be to the Lord, O that of might art mo≈øt:
To God the father and the Sonne, and to the holy Gho≈øt.
As it in the beginning was, for euer heretofore:
And is now at this pre≈øent tyme, and ≈øhalbe euermore.

div.head: The ≈øong of Saint Ambro≈øe, called Te deum.
div.p:
„Äà‚ô´„Äâ
WE pray≈øe thee God, we knowledge thee, the „Äà‚ô´„Äâ onely Lord to be, and as eternal father al the „Äà‚ô´„Äâ earth doth wor≈øhip thee. To thee al angels cry, the heaueÃÑs & all the „Äà‚ô´„Äâ powers therin: To thee Cherub & Seraphin, to crie they do not linne.

lg.l: O Holy, Holy, Holy, Lord, of Saboth Lord the God:
Through heauÃÑ & earth thy prai≈øe is ≈øpred, & glory al abrod.
Thapo≈øtles glorious company, yelde pray≈øes vnto thee:
The prophetes good ly felow≈øhip, pray≈øe thee continually.
The noble and victorious ho≈øt, of Martirs ≈øound thy pray≈øe:
The holy Church throughout the world doth knowledge thee alwayes,
Father of endles maie≈øtie, they do acknowledge thee:
Thy Chri≈øt, thine honorable, true and onely ≈øonne to be.
The holy Gho≈øt the comforter, of glory thou art kyng,
O Chri≈øt, and of the father art, the ≈øonne euerla≈øtyng.
When ≈øinfull mans decay in hand, thou tooke≈øt to re≈øtore:
To be enclo≈ød in virgins womb, thou didde≈øt not abhorre.
When thou had≈øt ouercome of death, the ≈øharp & cruell might,
Thou heaueÃÑs kingdom did≈øt ≈øet ope, to ech beleuing wight.
In glory of the father thou, doo≈øt ≈øit on Gods right hand:
We tru≈øt that thou ≈øhalt come our iudge, our cau≈øe to vnder≈øtand.
Lord helpe thy ≈øeruaÃÑts whoÃÑ thou ha≈øt, bought wt thy precious bloud
And in eternall glory ≈øet them with thy ≈øaintes ≈øo good.
O Lord do thou thy people ≈øaue, ble≈ø≈øe thine inheritaunce,
Lord gouerne them, and Lord do thou, for euer them aduaunce.
We magnifie thee day by day, and world without end,
Adore thy holy name (O Lord) Vouche≈øafe vs to defend
From ≈øinne this day. Haue mercy Lord, haue mercy on vs all:
And on vs (as we tru≈øt in thee) Lord let thy mercy fall.
O Lord I haue repo≈øed all, my confidence in thee:
Put to confounding ≈øhame therefore Lord let me neuer be.

div.head: ¬∂The ≈øong of the three Children, pray≈øing God, prouokyng all creatures to do the ≈øame.
div.p:
„Äà‚ô´„Äâ
O Alye workes of god the Lord bles ye the „Äà‚ô´„Äâ Lord, prai≈øe him & magnifie him for euer.

verse 4 O ye waters aboue the ≈økye, bles ye the Lord. &c.
verse 5 O ye the powers of the Lord, bles ye the Lord. &c.
verse 6 O ye the ≈øhining ≈øunne & moone, bles ye the Lord. &c.
verse 7 O ye the gli≈øtring ≈øtarres of heaueÃÑ, bles ye the Lord. &c.
verse 8 O ye the ≈øhowers & dropping dew, bles ye ye Lord. &c.
verse 9 O ye the blowing windes of god, bles ye the Lord. &c.
verse 10 O ye the fire & warming heate, bles ye the Lord. &c.
verse 11 Ye winter and the ≈øommer tyde, bles ye the Lord. &c.
verse 12 O ye the dewes & binding fro≈øtes, bles ye the Lord. &c.
verse 13 O ye the fro≈øt and chilling cold, bles ye the Lord. &c.
verse 14 O ye congeled i≈øe and ≈ønow, bles ye the Lord. &c.
verse 15 O ye ye nightes & light≈øome dayes, bles ye the lord. &c
verse 16 O ye the darknes and the light, bles ye the Lord. &c.
verse 17 O ye the lightnings & the cloudes bles ye the lord. &c
verse 18 O let the earth eke bles ye Lord, bles yea the Lord. &c
verse 19 O ye the mountaines & the hils, ble≈ø≈øe ye the lord. &c.
verse 20 O al ye grene things on the earth, bles ye the lord. &c
verse 21 O ye the euer ≈øpringing wels, bles ye the Lord. &c.
verse 22 O ye the ≈øeas and ye the flouds, bles ye the Lord &c.
verse 23 Whales & al that in waters moue, bles ye the lord &c
verse 24 O al ye flying foules of thayre, bles ye the Lord &c.
verse 25 O al the bea≈øtes and cattel eke, bles ye the Lorde. &c.
verse 26 O ye the children of mankind, bles ye the Lord. &c.
verse 27 Let I≈ørael eke ble≈ø≈øe the Lord, bles ye the Lord. &c
verse 28 O ye the prie≈øtes of God the Lord, bles ye the lord. &c
verse 29 O ye the ≈øeruantes of the Lord, bles ye the Lord &c.
verse 30 Ye ≈øprites & ≈øoules of righteous meÃÑ, ble≈ø≈øe ye ye lord &c

verse 32 O Ananias bles the Lord, bles thou the Lord,
prai≈øe him and magnify him for euer.
O Azarias bles the Lord, bles thou the Lord,
prai≈øe him and magnify him for euer.

pray≈øe him and magnify hym for euer.

div.head: ¬∂The ≈øong of Zacharias called Benedictus.
div.p:
„Äà‚ô´„Äâ
THe onely lord of I≈ørael be prai≈øed euermore: „Äà‚ô´„Äâ for through his vi≈øitation, and mercy kept in „Äà‚ô´„Äâ ≈øtore, His peoplenow he hath redemde, that long hath bene in thral, „Äà‚ô´„Äâ and ≈øpread abrode his ≈øauyng health, vpon his ≈øeruantes al.

lg.l: In Dauids hou≈øe his ≈øeruant true, according to his mynde:
And al≈øo his annoynted king, as we in Scripture fynde.
As by his holy prophetes al, oft times he did declare:
The which were ≈øince ye world began, his way for to prepare
That we might be deliuered, from tho≈øe that make debate:
Our enemies and from the handes, of all that do vs hate.
The mercy which he promi≈øed, our fathers to fulfil:
And thinke vpon his couenant made, according to his wyl.
And al≈øo to performe the othe, which he before had ≈øworne:
To Abraham our father deare, for vs that were forlorne.
That he would geue him≈øelfe for vs, and vs froÃÑ boÃÑdage bryng:
Out of the hands of al our foes, to ≈øerue our heauenly king.
And that without al maner feare, and eke in rightuou≈ønes:
And al≈øo for to leade our lyfe, in ≈øtedfa≈øt holines.
And yu (O child) which now art borne, and of the Lord elect:
Shalt be the prophet of the highe≈øt, his wayes for to dyrect.
For thou ≈øhalt go before his face, for to prepare his wayes:
And al≈øo for to teach his wil and plea≈øure all thy dayes.
To geue them knowledge how that their, ≈øaluation is nere:
And that remi≈ø≈øion of their ≈øins, is through his mercy mere.
Wherby the day ≈øpring from an hie, is come vs for to vi≈øit:
And tho≈øe for to illuminate, which do in darkenes ≈øit.
To lighten tho≈øe that ≈øhadowed be, with death & eke oppre≈øt:
And al≈øo for to guide their feete, the way to peace and re≈øt.

div.head: The ≈øong of ble≈ø≈øed Mary, called Magnificat.
div.p:
„Äà‚ô´„Äâ
MY ≈øoule doth magnify the Lord, my ≈øprite eke „Äà‚ô´„Äâ euermore, reioy≈øeth in the lord my god, which „Äà‚ô´„Äâ is my Sauior. And why? becau≈øe he did regard, & gaue re≈øpect vnto,
„Äà‚ô´„Äâ ≈øo ba≈øe e≈øtate of his hadmaid, and let the mighty go.

lg.l: For now behold al nations, and generations all:
From this tyme forth for euermore, ≈øhal me right ble≈ø≈øed cal.
Becau≈øe he hath me magnifyed, which is the Lord of might:
Who≈øe name be euer ≈øanctified, and pray≈øed day and night.
For with his mercy and his grace, all men he doth inflame:
Throughout al generations, to ≈øuch as feare his name.
He ≈øhewed ≈øtrength wt his great arme, & made ye proud to ≈øtart:
With al imaginations, that they bare in their hart.
He hath put downe the mighty ones, from their ≈øupernal ≈øeat:
And did exalt the meeke in hart, as he hath thought it meete
The hungry he repleni≈øhed, with al thyngs that were good:
And through his power he made ye rich, oft times to waÃÑt their fode.
And calling to remembraunce, his mercy euery deale:
Hath holpen vp a≈ø≈øi≈øtantly, his ≈øeruant I≈øraell.
According to his promi≈øe made, to Abraham before:
And to his ≈øeede ≈øucce≈ø≈øiuely, to ≈øtand for euermore.

div.head: The ≈øong of Simeon called Nunc dimittis.
div.p:
„Äà‚ô´„Äâ
O Lord becau≈øe my hartes de≈øire, hath wi≈øhed „Äà‚ô´„Äâ long to ≈øee, my onely lord & ≈øauiour, thy ≈øon be „Äà‚ô´„Äâ
‚Ä¢ ore I die, the ioy & health of al mankind, de≈øired long before, which „Äà‚ô´„Äâ now is come into the world, of mercy bringing ≈øtore.

lg.l: Thou ≈øuffere≈øt thy ≈øeruaunt now, in peace for to depart:
Accordyng to thy holy worde, which lighteneth my hart.
Becau≈øe mine eyes which thou ha≈øt made, to geue my body light:
Haue now behold thy ≈øauing health, which is the Lorde of myght
Whom thou mercifully ha≈øt ≈øet, of thyne aboundant grace:
In open ≈øight and vi≈øible, before all peoples face.
The Gentils to illuminate, and Sathan ouerquel:
And eke to be the glory of, thy people I≈ørael.

div.head: The Creede of Athana≈øius.
div.p:
„Äà‚ô´„Äâ
WHat man ≈øoeuer he be that, ≈øaluatioÃÑ wil attain „Äà‚ô´„Äâ the catholike beliefe he mu≈øt, before al things „Äà‚ô´„Äâ retaine. Which faith vnles he holy kepe, and vndefiledly, without „Äà‚ô´„Äâ al doubt eternally, he ≈øhal be ≈øure to dye.

lg.l: The catholike beliefe is this, that God we wor≈øhip one:
In Trinitie and Trinitie, in vnitie alone.
So as we neyther do confound, the per≈øons of the three:
Nor yet the ≈øub≈øtance whole of one, in ≈øunder parted bee.
One per≈øon of the father is, another of the Sonne:
An other per≈øon proper of, the holy gho≈øt alone.
Of father, Sonne, and holy Gho≈øt, but one the Godhed is:
Like glory coeternal eke, the maie≈øtie likewy≈øe.
Such as the father is, ≈øuch is the Sonne in ech degree:
And ≈øuch al≈øo we do beleue, the holy Gho≈øt to bee.
Vncreate is the Father, and vncreate is the Sonne:
The holy gho≈øt vncreate: ≈øo vncreate is ech one.
Incomprehen≈øible Father is, incomprehen≈øible Sonne:
And comprehen≈øible al≈øo is, the holy Gho≈øt of none.
The Father is eternal, and the Sonne eternall ≈øo:
And in lyke ≈øort eternal is, the holy gho≈øt al≈øo.
And yet though we beleue, that eche of the≈øe eternals bee:
Yet there but one eternal is, and not eternals three.
As ne incomprehen≈øible we, ne yet vncreat three:
But one incomprehen≈øible one, vncreate holde to bee.
Almighty ≈øo the father is, the ≈øonne almighty ≈øo:
And in lyke ≈øort almighty is, the holy Gho≈øt al≈øo.
And albeit that euery one, of the≈øe almighty bee:
yet there but one almighty is, and not almighties three.
The father God is, God the Sonne, God holy Gho≈øt al≈øo:
yet are there not three Gods in al, but one God and no mo.
So like wi≈øe Lord the Father is, and Lord al≈øo the Sonne:
And lord the holy gho≈øt, yet are there not thre lords but one.
For as we are compeld to graunt, by chri≈øtian veritie,
Eche of the per≈øons by hymfelfe, both God and Lord to be:
So catholike religion, forbiddeth vs alway:
That eyther gods be three, or yt there lordes be three to ≈øay.
Of none the father, is ne made, ne create, nor begot:
The Sonne is of the Father, not create ne made, but got.
The holy Gho≈øt is of them both, the father and the Sonne:
He made, ne create, nor begot, but doth proceede alone.
So we one Father hold, not three, one Sonne al≈øo not three:
One holy Gho≈øt alone, and not three holy Gho≈øtes to bee.
None in this Trinitie before, nor after other is:
Ne greater any then the re≈øt, ne le≈ø≈øer be likewi≈øe.
But euery one among them≈øelues, of all the per≈øons three:
Together coeternal al, and al coequal bee.
So vnitie in Trinitie, as ≈øaid it is before:
And Trinitie in vnitie, in all thynges we adore.
Therfore what man ≈øoeuer that, ≈øaluation wil attayne:
This faith touching the Trinitie, of force he mu≈øt retayne.
And nedeful to eternal lyfe, it is that euery wight.
Of the incarnating of Chri≈øt, our Lord beleue aright.
For this the right faith is that we, beleue and eke beknow:
That Chri≈øt our lord ye ≈øon of God, is God and man al≈øo.
God of his fathers ≈øub≈øtance got, before the world began:
And of his mothers ≈øub≈øtance borne, in world a very man.
Both perfect god, and perfect man, in one one Ie≈øus Chri≈øt:
That doth of rea≈øonable ≈øoule, and humaine fle≈øh ≈øub≈øi≈øt.
Touchyng hys Godhode, equal with his father God is he:
Touching his manhode lower then, his father in degree.
Who though he be both very God, and very man al≈øo:
yet is he but one Chri≈øt alone, and is not per≈øons two.
One, not by turning of Godhode, into the fle≈øh of man:
But by takyng manhode to God, this beyng one began.
All one, not by confounding of, the ≈øub≈øtance into one:
But onely by the vnitie, that is of one per≈øon.
For as the rea≈øonable ≈øoule, and fle≈øh but one man is:
So in one per≈øon God and man, is but one Chri≈øt lykewy≈øe.
Who ≈øuffred for to ≈øaue vs all, to hell he did de≈øcend:
The third day ro≈øe agayne froÃÑ death, to heauen he did a≈øceÃÑd.
He ≈øittes at the ryght hand of God, the almighty father there:
From thence to iudge the quicke & dead, againe he ≈øhal retire.
At who≈øe returne all men ≈øhall ri≈øe, with bodies new re≈øtorde:
And of their own workes they ≈øhal geue accoÃÑpt vnto ye lord.
And they into eternal lyfe ≈øhall go, that haue done wel:
Who haue done il, ≈øhal go into eternal fire to dwel.
This is the Catholike beliefe, who doth not faithfully
Beleue the ≈øame, without al dout, he ≈øaued cannot be.
To Father, Sonne, and holy gho≈øt, al glory be therfore:
As in beginning was, is now, and ≈øhalbe euermore.

div.head: The Lamentation of a ≈øynner.
div.p:
„Äà‚ô´„Äâ
O Lord turne not away thy face, froÃÑ him that „Äà‚ô´„Äâ lieth pro≈øtrate: Lamenting ≈øore his ≈øinful life „Äà‚ô´„Äâ before thy mercy gate. Which gate thou opene≈øt wide to tho≈øe, yt do „Äà‚ô´„Äâ lament their ≈øin: ≈øhut not yr gate again≈øt me lord, but let me enter in.

lg.l: And call me not to mine accomptes, howe I haue liued here:
For then I know right well (O Lord) how vile I ≈øhall appeare.
I nede not to confe≈ø≈øe my lyfe, I am ≈øure thou can≈øt tell:
what I haue ben, and what I am, I know thou knowe≈øt it wel.
O Lord thou knowe≈øt what things be pa≈øt, & eke the things that bee,
Thou knowe≈øt al≈øo what is to come, nothing is hid from thee.
Before ye heaueÃÑs & earth wer made, yu knowe≈øt what things wer theÃÑ,
As all things els that haue ben ≈øince, among the ≈øonnes of men.
And can the thinges that I haue done, be hidden from thee then?
Nay, nay, yu knowe≈øt theÃÑ all, O Lord, where they wer done & wheÃÑ.
Wherfore with teares I come to thee, to begge and to entreate:
Euen as the child that hath done euill, and feareth to be beate.
So come I to thy mercy gate, where mercy doth abound:
Requiring mercy for my ≈øinne, to heale my deadly wounde,
O Lord I nede not to repeate, what I do begge or craue,
Thou knowe≈øt, O Lord, before I a≈øke, ye thing that I would haue.
Mercy, good Lord, mercy I a≈øke, this is the totall ≈øumme:
For mercy Lord is all my ≈øute, Lord let thy mercy come.

div.head: The humble ≈øute of a ≈øinner.
div.p:
„Äà‚ô´„Äâ
O Lord of whom I do depeÃÑd be hold my care. „Äà‚ô´„Äâ full hart, & wheÃÑ thy will & plea≈øure is relea≈øe „Äà‚ô´„Äâ me of my ≈ømart, yu ≈øee≈øt my ≈øorowes what they are, my gref is knowne „Äà‚ô´„Äâ to thee, and there is none that caÃÑ remoue, or take the ≈øame froÃÑ me.

lg.l: But onely thou who≈øe ayde I craue, who≈øe mercy ≈øtil is pre≈øt:
To ea≈øe all tho≈øe that come to thee for ≈øuccour and for re≈øt.
And ≈øith thou ≈øee≈øt my re≈øtles eyes, my teares & greuous grone.
AtteÃÑde vnto my ≈øute, O Lord, marck wel my plaint & mone.
For ≈øinne hath ≈øo inclo≈øed me, and compa≈øt me about:

For mortall man, cannot realea≈øe, or mitigate this payne:
But eueÃÑ thy Chri≈øt, my lord & god, which for my ≈øinnes was ≈ølaine.
Wo≈øe bloudy wouÃÑdes are yet to ≈øee, though not with mortall eye:
yet doth thy ≈øaints behold them all, and ≈øo I tru≈øt ≈øhall I.
Though ≈øinne doth hinder me a while, when thou ≈øhalt ≈øee it good:
I ≈øhall nioy the ≈øight of him, and ≈øee his woundes and bloud.

But whiles I lyue here in this vale, where ≈øinners do frequent:
A≈ø≈øi≈øt me euer with thy grace, my ≈øinnes ≈øtill to lament.
Lea≈øt that I treade in ≈øinners trace, and geue them my con≈øent,
To dwell with them in wickednes, wherto nature is bent.
Onely thy grace mu≈øt be my ≈øtay, lea≈øt that I fall down flat:
And beyng down, then of my ≈øelfe cannot recouer that.
Wherfore this is yet once agayne, my ≈øute and my reque≈øt:
To graunt me pardon for my ≈øinne, that I in thee may re≈øt.
Then ≈øhall my hart, my tong and voyce, be in≈øtruments of pray≈øe,
And in thy church & hou≈øe of ≈øaints, ≈øing P≈øalmes to thee alwaies.

div.head: The Lordes Prayer, or Pater no≈øter.
div.p:
„Äà‚ô´„Äâ
OVr father which in heaueÃÑ art, lord halowd be „Äà‚ô´„Äâ thy name, thy kingdom come, thy wil be done „Äà‚ô´„Äâ in earth, euen as the ≈øame in heaueÃÑ is. Geue vs, O Lord, our dayly „Äà‚ô´„Äâ bread this day: As we forgeue our detters ≈øo, Forgeue our dettes
„Äà‚ô´„Äâ we pray. Into temptation leade vs not, From euill make vs free, „Äà‚ô´„Äâ for kingdome, power and glory thine, both now and euer be.

div.head: The .x. Commaundementes of Almighty God. Audi I≈ørael. Exod. xx.
div.p:
„Äà‚ô´„Äâ
HArke I≈øraell, and what I ≈øay, geue hede to „Äà‚ô´„Äâ vnder≈øtaÃÑd. I am the Lord thy God ye brought „Äà‚ô´„Äâ thee out of Egipt laÃÑd, eueÃÑ froÃÑ the hou≈øe wherin yu did≈øt in thraldoÃÑ liue „Äà‚ô´„Äâ a ≈ølaue: None other gods at all before my pre≈øence ≈øhalt thou haue.

lg.l: No maner grauen image ≈øhalt thou make at all to thee:
Nor any figure like by thee, ≈øhall counterfayted bee,
Of any thing in heauen aboue, nor in the earth below,
Nor in waters beneath the earth, to theÃÑ thou ≈øhalt not bow.
Nor ≈øhalt them ≈øerue. The Lord thy God, a ielous God am I,
That puni≈øh parentes faultes vnto the third and fourth degree,
Vpon their children that me hate: and mercy do di≈øplay,

The name thou of the Lord thy God, in vayne ≈øhalt neuer v≈øe:

No worke then ≈øhalt thou do in it, ne thou nor yet thy ≈øonne,
Thy daughter, ≈øeruauÃÑt, nor handmayd, thine Oxe, nor yet thine A≈ø≈øe:

For in ≈øixe dayes God heauen, and earth, and all therin did make,

Wherfore he ble≈øt the day that he, for re≈øting did ordayne,

yeld honor to thy parentes, that prolongd thy dayes may be
VpoÃÑ the land, the which the Lord, thy God hath geueÃÑ thee.
Thou ≈øhalt not murther. Thou ≈øhalt not commit adultery:

div.head: Beatus vir. i.

argument.p: ¬∂Whether it was E≈øoras, or any other that gathered the P≈øalmes into a booke: it ≈øemeth he did ≈øet this P≈øalme fir≈øt in maner of a Preface, to exhorte all godly men to ≈øtudy and meditate the heauenly wi≈ødome, for theffect hereof is, that they be ble≈ø≈øed that geue them ≈øelues wholy all their lyfe to Gods law: And that the wicked contemners of god, though they ≈øeme for a while fortunate, yet at length ≈øhall come to mi≈øerable de≈øtruction,

div.p:
„Äà‚ô´„Äâ

div.head: Quare fremuerunt gentes. P≈øalme .ii.

argument.p: ¬∂Dauid reioy≈øeth, that notwith≈øtanding his enemies rage, and worldly power, yet god will continue his kingdome for euer, and aduauÃÑce it euen to the formo≈øt, end of the world. And therfore he exhorteth kinges and rulers, that ≈øetting vayne glory a part, they would humble ≈øubmit them ≈øelues vnder gods yoke. Herein is ≈øign ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed Chri≈øt and his kingdome.

div.head: Domine quid multiplicati. P≈øalme .iii.

argument.p: ¬∂Dauid being per≈øecuted, and driuen out of his kingdome by his owne ≈øonne Ab≈øalon, was greatly tormented in minde for his ≈øinne again≈øt god: and therfore calleth vpon god, and waxeth holde through his promi≈øes, agayn≈øt the great terrors of his enemies: yea, and again≈øt death it ≈øelf, which he ≈øaw pre≈øent before his eyes. Finally he reioy≈øeth for the good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe and victory, that god gaue him and all the Church ouer his enemies.

div.p:
„Äà‚ô´„Äâ
O Lord how are my foes increa≈øt, which vexe „Äà‚ô´„Äâ me more and more? They kil my hart when „Äà‚ô´„Äâ as they ≈øay: God can him not re≈øtore, but thou. O Lord, art my „Äà‚ô´„Äâ defence, when I am hard be≈øtead, my wor≈øhyp and myne honour „Äà‚ô´„Äâ both, and thou hold≈øt vp my head.
div.l: verse 4 Then with my voyce vpon the Lord, I did both cal and cry:
And he out of his holy hill, did heare me by and by.

div.head: Cum inuocarem exaudiui. P≈øalme .iiii.

argument.p: ¬∂WheÃÑ Saul per≈øecuted Dauid, he called vpon God, tru≈øting mo≈øt a≈ø≈øuredly in his promi≈øe, & therfore holdly reproueth his enemies, who by wilfull malice re≈øi≈øted his dominion. Let vs lykewi≈øe learne to tru≈øt in gods promi≈øes, when we are afflicted with any kinde of Cro≈ø≈øe, and ≈øo we ≈øhall neither feare our enemies, nor yet be ouer commen with tentations.

div.head: Verba mea auribus percipe. P≈øalme .v.

argument.p: ¬∂Dauid hauing ≈øuffered great calamitie, as well by Doeg a Achitophel Saules flatterers, as by other infinite enemies, calleth to God for ≈øuccor, ≈øhewing how requi≈øite it is, that God ≈øhould puni≈øhe the malicious enuy of his aduer≈øaries. After beyng a≈ø≈øured of pro≈øperous ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, he conceyueth comforte: concludyng, that when God ≈øhall deliuer hym, other al≈øo ≈øhall be partakers of the ≈øame mercies.

div.head: i. Domine ne in furore tuo. P≈øalme .vi.

argument.p: ¬∂When Dauid by his ≈øinnes hath prouoked gods wrath, and now felt not onely his hand again≈øt him, but al≈øo conceiued the horrors of death euerla≈øtyng: he de≈øired forgeuenes, bewayling that if god toke him awaye in his indignation, he ≈øhould lacke occa≈øion to pray≈øe him as he was wont to do while≈øt he was amonge≈øt men. Then ≈øodenly feling gods mercy, he ≈øharpely rebuketh his enemies, whiche reioy≈øeth in his affliction.

div.p:
„Äà‚ô´„Äâ
LOrde in thy wrath reproue me not thoughe I „Äà‚ô´„Äâ de≈øerue thine ire: Ne yet correct me in thy rage, „Äà‚ô´„Äâ O Lorde I thee de≈øire. For I am weake therfore, O Lorde, of „Äà‚ô´„Äâ mercy me forbeare, and heale me Lord: for why, thou knowe≈øt my „Äà‚ô´„Äâ bones do quake for feare.
div.l: verse 3 My ≈øoule is troubled very ≈øore, and vexed vehemently,
But Lord how long wilt thou delay, to cure my mi≈øery?

Finally be doth prouoke all creatures to pray≈øes, prophecying of the kyngdome of Chri≈øt, and the buildyng of Iuda, where all the faythfull and theyr ≈øeede ≈øhall dwell for euer.

And al the law of God our Lord, he dyd it ful obey:
and for our ≈øins vpon the cro≈ø≈øe, hys bloud our dets did pay
And y‚Ä¢ we ≈øhould not yet forget, what good he to vs wrought
A ≈øygne he left our eyes to tel, that he our bodies bought.
In bread & wyne here vi≈øible, vnto thine eyes and ta≈øt:
his mercies great thou mai≈øt record, if that his ≈øprite yu ha≈øt.
As once the corn did liue & grow, and was cut down with ≈øithe
and thre≈øhed out with many ≈øtripes, out froÃÑ his hu≈øk to driue
And as the mil with violence, did teare it out ≈øo ≈ømal:
and made it lyke to earthly du≈øt, not ≈øparyng it at al.
And as the ouen with fyre whote, did clo≈øe it vp in heat:
and al this done that I haue ≈øaid, that it ≈øhould be our meat
So was the Lord in his ripe age, cut down by cruel death:
his ≈øoule he gaue in torments great, & yelded vp his breath.
Becau≈øe that he to vs might be, an euerla≈øtyng bread:
with much reproch and trouble great, on earth his life he led
And as the grapes in plea≈øant tyme, are pre≈ø≈øed very ≈øore:
and plucked down wheÃÑ thei be ripe, not let to grow no more
Becau≈øe the iuy≈øe that in them is, as comfortable drinke:
He might receiue & ioyful be, wheÃÑ ≈øorowes make vs ≈øhrink
So chri≈øtes bloud out pre≈ø≈øed was, with nayles & eke with ≈øpeare:
The iui≈øe wherof doth ≈øaue al tho≈øe, that rightly do him feare.
And as the cornes by vnitie, into one loafe is knit:
So is the Lord and his whole church, though he in heauen ≈øit.
As many grapes make but one wyne, ≈øo ≈øhould we be but one,
In fayth and loue, in Chri≈øt aboue, and vnto Chri≈øt alone.
Leading a lyfe without all ≈øtryfe, in quiet re≈øt and peace:
From enuy and from malice both, our hartes and tonges to cea≈øe.
Which if we do, then ≈øhal we ≈øhew, that we his cho≈øen be:
By faith in him to lead a lyfe, as alwayes willed he.
And that we may ≈øo do in dede, God ≈øend vs al his grace:
Then after death we ≈øhal be ≈øure, with hym to haue a place.

div.p:
„Äà‚ô´„Äâ
PRe≈øerue vs Lord by thy dere word, froÃÑ Turk „Äà‚ô´„Äâ and Pope defend vs Lord, which both would „Äà‚ô´„Äâ thru≈øt out of his throne, our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt thy deare ≈øonne.
div.l: Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt ≈øhew forth thy might,
That thou art Lord of Lordes by ryght:
Thy poore afflicted flock defend,
That they may pray≈øe thee without end.
God holy Gho≈øt our comfortor, ‚ùß
Be our Patrone, help, and ≈øuccor:
Geue vs one mind, and perfect peace,
All gifts of grace in vs encrea≈øe.
Thou liuing God, in per≈øons three,
Thy name be pray≈øed in vnitie.
In all our nede ≈øo vs defend:
That we may prai≈øe thee, world without end.

div.head: ¬∂A forme of Prayer to be v≈øed in priuate hou≈øes, euery morning and euenyng.
¬∂Mornyng prayer.
div.p: ALmighty God & mo≈øt merciful father, we do not pre≈øent our ≈øelues here before thy maie≈øty, tru≈øting in our owne merites or worthines, but in thy manifold mercies, which ha≈øt promi≈øed to heare our prayers, & grauÃÑt our reque≈øts, which we ≈øhal make to thee in y‚Ä¢ name of thy beloued ≈øon Ie≈øus Chri≈øt our Lord: who hath al≈øo commaunded vs to a≈ø≈øemble our ≈øelues together in his name, with ful a≈ø≈øurance that he wil not onely be amoÃÑg≈øt vs, but al≈øo be our mediator and aduocate towards thy maie≈øtie, that we may obtayne all thinges which ≈øhal ≈øeme expedient to thy ble≈ø≈øed wil for our nece≈ø≈øities: therfore we be≈øech thee mo≈øt merciful Father, to turne thy louyng countenance towardes vs, and impute not vnto vs our manifold ≈øinnes and offences, wherby we iu≈øtly de≈øerue thy wrath & ≈øharp puni≈øhment, but rather receyue vs to thy mercye for Ie≈øus Chri≈øtes ≈øake, accepting his death and pa≈ø≈øion as a iu≈øt recompence for all our offences, in whom onely thou art plea≈øed, and through whom thou can≈øt not be offended with vs. And ≈øeyng that of thy great mercies we haue quietly pa≈ø≈øed this nyght, graunt (O heauenly Father) that we may be≈øtow this day wholy in thy ≈øeruice, ≈øo that al our thoughts words, and dedes, may redouÃÑd to the glory of thy name, and good en≈øample to al men, who ≈øeyng our good workes, may glorify thee our heauenly father. And for as much as of thy mere fauour and ‚Ä¢ oue, thou ha≈øt not onely created vs to thyne own ≈øimilitude and lykenes, but al≈øo ha≈øt cho≈øen vs to be heyres with thy deare Sonne Ie≈øus Chri≈øt of that immortal kingdom which thou prepared≈øt for vs before the beginning of ye world, we be≈øech thee to encrea≈øe our faith & knowledge, and to lighten our harts with thy holy ≈øprite, that we may in y‚Ä¢ mean tyme, liue in godly conuer≈øation and integrity of lyfe, knowyng that Idolaters, adulterers, couetous men, coÃÑtentious per≈øons, drunkards, gluttons, and ≈øuch like, ≈øhal not inherite the kingdom of God.

And becau≈øe thou ha≈øt commaunded vs to pray one for an other, we do not onely make reque≈øt (O Lord) for our ≈øelues, and them that thou ha≈øt already called to the true vnderdandyng of thy heauenlye wil: but for all people & nations of the world, who as they know by thy wonderful workes, that thou art God ouer al: ≈øo they may be in≈øtructed by thy holy ≈øpirit, to beleue in thee theyr onely Sauiour & redemer. But for as much as they cannot beleue except they heare, nor cannot heare, but by preachyng, and none can preache except they be
≈øent: therfore (O Lord) ray≈øe vp faithful di≈øtributers of thy mi≈øteries, who ≈øettyng apart al worldly re≈øpects, may both in their lyfe & doctrine onely ≈øeeke thy glory. Contrarily confound Sathan, Antichri≈øt, with all hyrelinges, whome thou ha≈øt already ca≈øt of into a reprobate ≈øence, that they may not by ≈øectes, ≈øchi≈ømes, here≈øies, and errours, di≈øquiete thy little flocke. And becau≈øe (O Lord) we be fallen into the latter dayes and daungerous tymes, wherein ignoraunce hath gotten the vpper hand, and Sathan by his mini≈øters ≈øeke by all meanes to quenche the light of thy Go≈øpell, we be≈øech thee to maintayne thy cau≈øe again≈øt tho≈øe rauenyng wolues, and ≈øtrengthen al thy ≈øeruants whom they keepe in pri≈øon and bondage. Let not thy long ≈øuffryng be an occa≈øion, eyther to encrea≈øe their tiranny, or to di≈øcourage thy children, neyther yet let our ≈øynnes and wickednes be a hynderaunce to thy mercies, but with ≈øpeede (O Lord) con≈øider the≈øe great mi≈øeries. For thy people I≈øraell many tymes by their ≈øynnes prouoked thyne anger, and thou puni≈øhed≈øt them by thy iu≈øt iudgement, yet thoughe theyr ≈øynnes were neuer ≈øo greuous, if they once returned from theyr iniquity, thou receyued≈øt them to mercy. We therefore mo≈øt wretched ≈øynners, be wayle our manifolde ≈øynnes, and earne≈øtly repent vs for our former wyckednes and vngodly behauiour towardes thee: and where as we cannot of our ≈øelues purcha≈øe thy pardon, yet we humbly be≈øech thee for Ie≈øus Chri≈øtes ≈øake, to ≈øhew thy mercies vpon vs, and receyue vs againe to thy fauour. Graunt vs dere father the≈øe our reque≈øts and al other thynges nece≈ø≈øary for vs, and thy whole church according to thy promi≈øe in Ie≈øus Chri≈øt our lord. In who≈øe name we be≈øech thee as he hath taught vs, ≈øaying. Our father. &c.

div.head: A prayer to be ≈øayd before meales.
div.p:
ALl thynges depend vppon thy prouidence (O Lord) to receyue at thy hands due ≈øu≈øtenance in time conuenient, thou geue≈øt to them and they gather it, thou opene≈øt thy hande, and they are ≈øati≈øfied with al good things. O heauenly father which art the fountayne & ful trea≈øure of al goodnes, we be≈øeche thee to ≈øhew thy mercies vpon vs thy children, & ≈øanctify the≈øe gyfts which we receyue of thy mercifull liberality, graunt vs grace to v≈øe them ≈øoberly and purely accordyng to thy ble≈ø≈øed wyll, ≈øo that hereby we maye acknowledge thee to bee the author and geuer of all good things, and aboue al, that we may remember continually, to ≈øeeke the ≈øpirituall fo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e of thy worde, wherwith our ≈øoules may be nouri≈øhed euerla≈øtingly, through our ≈øauior Chri≈øt: who is the true bread of life,
which came down from heauen, of whom who≈øoeuer eateth, ≈øhal liue for euer, and raigne with him in glory world without end So be it.

div.head: A thankes geuyng after meales.
div.p: LEt all nations magnify the Lord, let all people reioyce, in pray≈øing and extollyng hys great mercies. For his fatherly kyndnes is plentifully ≈øhewd forth vpon vs, and the truth of his promi≈øe endureth for euer.

We render thankes vnto thee (O Lorde God) for the manifolde benefites, which we continually receiue at thy bountiful hand, not onely for that it hath plea≈øed thee to frede vs, in this pre≈øent lyfe, geuyng vnto vs all thinges nece≈ø≈øary for the ≈øame: but e≈øpecially becau≈øe thou ha≈øt of thy free mercies fa≈øhioned vs a new, into an a≈ø≈øured hope of a far better lyfe, the which thou ha≈øt declared vnto vs by thy holy Go≈øpell. Therfore we humbly be≈øech thee (O heauenly father) that thou wilte not ≈øuffer our affections to bee ≈øo intangled or rooted in the≈øe earthly and corruptible thyngs, but that we may alwayes haue our myndes dyrected to thee on high, coÃÑtinually watchyng for the coÃÑ myng of our Lord and Sauiour Chri≈øt, what time he ≈øhal appeare for our ful redemption. To whome with thee and the holy Gho≈øt, be all honour and glory, for euer and euer. So be it.

div.head: Another thankes geuyng before meales.
div.p: ETernall and euerlyuing God, Father of our Lorde Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, who of thy mo≈øt ≈øingular loue whiche thou beare≈øt to mankynde, ha≈øt appointed to his ≈øu≈øtenaunce, not onely the frutes of the earth, but al≈øo the foules of the ayre, the bea≈øtes of the earth, and fi≈øhes of the ≈øea, and ha≈øt commaunded thy benefits to be receyued, as from thy handes with thanks geuing, a≈ø≈øuring thy children by the mouth of thy Apo≈øtle, that to the cleane al things are cleane, as the creatures which be ≈øanctif ‚Ä¢ d by thy word & by prayer: graunt vnto vs ≈øo moderately to v≈øe the≈øe thy giftes pre≈øent, that the bodies being refre≈øhed, the ≈øoules may be more able to procede in all good workes, to the pray≈øe of thy holy name, through Ie≈øus Chri≈øte our Lord. So be it.
Our Father which art in heauen. &c.

div.head: Another.
div.p:
THe eyes of all things do looke vp and tru≈øt in thee (O Lord) thou geue≈øt them meat in due ≈øea≈øon, thou opene≈øt thy hande,
and fille≈øt with thy ble≈ø≈øing euery liuing creature: good Lord ble≈ø≈øe vs and al thy gifts, which we receiue of thy large liberality, through Ie≈øus Chri≈øt our Lord. So be it. Our father. &c.

div.head: Another thankes geuing after meat.
div.p: GLory, prai≈øe, & honor be vnto thee, mo≈øt mercifull and omnipotent father, who of thine infinite goodnes, ha≈øt created man to to thine owne image and ≈øimilitude: who al≈øo ha≈øt fed, and daily fede≈øt of thy mo≈øt bountiful hand all liuing creatures: graunt vnto vs, that as thou ha≈øt nouri≈øhed the≈øe our mortal bodies with corporal foode, ≈øo thou woulde≈øt repleni≈øhe our ≈øoules wyth the perfect knowledge of the liuely word of thy beloued ≈øonne Ie≈øus, to whoÃÑ be prai≈øe, glory and honor for euer. So be it.

¬∂God ≈øaue the church vniuer≈øal, our Quene and Realme: God coÃÑ fort all them that be comfortles. Lord increa≈øe our faith. O Lorde for Chri≈øt thy ≈øonnes ≈øake, be merciful to the coÃÑmon wealthes, where thy Go≈øpel is truely preached, and harbor graunted to the afflicted members of Chri≈øtes body, and illuminate accordyng to thy good plea≈øure al nations with the brightnes of thy word. So be it.

div.head: ¬∂Another.
div.p: THe God of glory and peace, who hath created, redemed, & pre≈øently fed vs, be ble≈ø≈øed for euer and euer. So be it.

¬∂The God of all power, who hath called from death, that great pa≈øtor of the ≈øhepe, our Lord Ie≈øus, comfort and defend the flock which he hath redemed by the bloud of the eternal te≈øtament, increa≈øe the number of true preachers: repres the rage of ob≈øtinate tirants, mitigate & lighteÃÑ the harts of the ignorant, relieue the paynes of ≈øuch as be afflicted, but e≈øpecially of tho≈øe y‚Ä¢ ≈øuffer for ye te≈øtimony of his truth, & finally confound SathaÃÑ by the power of our lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt. AmeÃÑ

div.head: Euening prayer.
div.p:
O Lord God fatherr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rla≈øting and ful of pitie, we acknowledge and confes, that we be not worthy to lift vp our eyes to heauen, muche les to pre≈øent our ≈øelues before thy maie≈øtye, wyth confidence that thou wilt heare our prayers, and graunte oure reque≈øtes, if we con≈øider our owne de≈øeruynges: for our con≈øciences do accu≈øe vs, and our ≈øynnes witnes again≈øt vs, and we knowe that thou art an vpright iudge, whiche doo≈øt not iu≈øtifye the ≈øynners and wycked men, but puni≈øhe≈øt the faults of al ≈øuch as tran≈øgre≈ø≈øe thy commaundementes. Yet mo≈øte mercifull father, ≈øince it hath plea≈øed thee to commaunde vs to cal on thee in all our troubles and aduer≈øities,
promi≈øing euen then to help vs, when we fele our ≈øelues (as it were) ≈øwalowed vp of death & de≈øperation, we vtterly renounce al worldly confidence, & flee to thy ≈øoueraign bouÃÑtie, as our onely ≈øtay & refuge: be≈øeching thee not to cal to remembraunce our manifold ≈øinnes & wickednes, wherby we continually prouoke thy wrath and indignation again≈øt vs: neither our negligence and vnkindnes, which haue neyther worthely e≈øtemed, nor in our liues ≈øufficieÃÑtly expre≈ø≈øed the ≈øwete comfort of thy go≈øpel reueled vnto vs: but rather to accept the obedience and death of thy ≈øonne Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, who by offring vp his body in ≈øacrifice once for all, hath made a ≈øufficient recompence for all our ≈øynnes. Haue mercy therfore vppon vs (O Lord) and forgeue vs our offences. Teach vs by thy holy Spirite, that we may ryghtly waye them, and earne≈øtly repent for the ≈øame. And ≈øo much the rather (O Lord) becau≈øe that the reprobate and ≈øuch as thou ha≈øt for≈øaken, cannot pray≈øe thee, nor cal vpon thy name, but the repenting hart, the ≈øorowful mynd, the con≈øcience oppre≈ø≈øed, hungring and thir≈øting for thy grace, ≈øhal euer ≈øet forth thy pray≈øe and glory. And albeit we be but wormes and du≈øt, yet thou art our creator, and we be the worke of thy hands: yea, thou art our father, and we thy children, thou art our ≈øhepeheard, and we thy flocke, thou art our redemer, and we the people whom thou ha≈øt bought: thou art our God, and we thyne inheritaunce. Correct vs not therfore in thyne anger (O Lord) neyther accordyng to our de≈øertes puni≈øh vs, but mercifully cha≈øtice vs wyth a fatherly affection, that all the world may know, that at what tyme ≈øoeuer a ≈øynner doth repent hym of hys ≈øinne from the bottome of his hart, thou wilt put away his wickednes out of thy remembraunce, as thou ha≈øt promi≈øed by thy holy Prophet.

Finally, for as much as it hath plea≈øed thee to make the nyght for man to re≈øt in, as thou ha≈øt ordayned hym the day to trauell, graunt (O deare father) that we may ≈øo take our bodily re≈øt, that our ≈øoules may continually watch, for the tyme that our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt ≈øhal appeare for our deliueraunce out of this mortal lyfe, and in the mean ≈øea≈øon that we, not ouercomen by any fanta≈øies, dreames, or other teÃÑptations, may fully ≈øet our myndes vpon thee, loue thee, feare thee, and re≈øt in thee: furthermore, that our ≈øleepe be not exce≈ø≈øiue or ouer much after the in≈øatiable de≈øires of our fle≈øh, but onely ≈øufficient to content our weake nature, that we may be better di≈øpo≈øed to lyue in all godly conuer≈øation to the glory of thy holy name, and profite of our brethren So be it.

div.head: ¬∂A Godly prayer to be ≈øayd at al times.
div.p: HOnor and pray≈øe, be geuen to thee (O Lord God almighty) mo≈øt deare father of heaueÃÑ for al thy mercies & louing kindnes ≈øhewed vnto vs, in yt it hath plea≈øed thy gratious goodnes frely and of thine owne accord, to elect and cho≈øe vs to ≈øaluation before the beginning of the world, and euen lyke continual thankes be geueÃÑ to thee for creating vs after thine own image, for redeming vs with the precious bloud of thy deare ≈øonne, wheÃÑ we were vtterly lo≈øt, for ≈øanctifying vs with thy holy ≈øpirit in the reuelation & knowledge of thy holy word, for helping and ≈øuccoryng vs, in al our nedes and nece≈ø≈øities, for ≈øauing vs from al daungers of body & ≈øoule, for comforting vs ≈øo fatherly in al our tribulatioÃÑs, and per≈øecutioÃÑs, for ≈øparing vs ≈øo long, and geuing vs ≈øo large a time of repeÃÑtaunce. The≈øe benefites (O mo≈øt merciful father) like as we knowledge to haue receiued them of thy onely goodnes, euen ≈øo we be≈øech thee, for thy deare ≈øonne Ie≈øus Chri≈øtes ≈øake: to grauÃÑt vs alwayes thy holy ≈øpirit, wherby we may continually grow in thaÃÑkfulnes towardes thee, to be led into al truth, and coÃÑforted in al our aduer≈øities. O Lord, ≈øtrengtheÃÑ our faith, kindle it more in feruentnes & loue towardes thee (& our neyghbours) for thy ≈øake. Suffer vs not mo≈øt deare Father, to receyue thy word any more in vayne: but graunt vs alwayes the a≈ø≈øi≈øtauÃÑce of thy grace and holy ≈øpirit, that in hart word and dede we may ≈øanctify and do wor≈øhip to thy name. Helpe to amplifie and increa≈øe „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ and what≈øoeuer thou ≈øende≈øt, we may be hartly wel conteÃÑt with thy good plea≈øure & wil: Let vs not lacke the thyng (O Father) without the which we caÃÑ not ≈øerue thee, but ble≈ø≈øe thou ≈øo al the workes of our handes, that we may haue ≈øufficient, and not to be chargeable but rather helpeful vnto others: be merciful (O Lord) to our offences, & ≈øeing our det is great, which thou ha≈øt forgeueÃÑ vs in Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, make vs to loue thee and our neighbours ≈øo much ye more. Be thou our father, our captaine and defender: in al temptations hold thou vs by thy merciful hand, that we may be deliuered from al inconueniences, and end our liues in the ≈øaÃÑctifying and honor of thy holy name through Ie≈øu Chri≈øt our Lord and onely Sauiour. So be it. Let thy mighty hand & out ≈øtretched arme (O Lord) be ≈øtil our defence, thy mercy and louyng kindnes in Ie≈øu Chri≈øt thy deare ≈øonne our ≈øaluation, thy true an holy word our in≈øtruction, thy grace and holy ≈øpirit our comfort and con≈øolation vnto the end and in the end. So be it.

div.head: ¬∂A Confe≈øsion for al e≈øtates and times.
div.p:
O Eternal God and mo≈øt merciful father we confe≈ø≈øe & acknowledge, here before thy diuine maie≈øtie, that wear mi≈øerable ≈øinners,
coÃÑceiued and borne in ≈øinne and iniquity, ≈øo that in vs there is no goodnes. For the fle≈øh euermore rebelleth again≈øt the ≈øpirite, wherby we continually tran≈øgres thy holy precepts & coÃÑmaundemeÃÑts, & ≈øo purchace to our ≈øelues through thy iu≈øt iudgemeÃÑt, death & daÃÑnation: Notwith≈øtanding (O heaueÃÑly father) for a≈ømuch as we are di≈øplea≈øed with our ≈øelues for the ≈øinnes that we haue coÃÑmitted agayn≈øt thee, & do vnfainedly repent vs of the ≈øame: we mo≈øt humbly be≈øech thee, for Ie≈øus Chri≈øts ≈øake, to ≈øhew thy mercy vpon vs, to forgeue vs al our ≈øinnes, & to increa≈øe thy holy ≈øpirit in vs y‚Ä¢, we acknowledging froÃÑ the botom of our harts, our own vnrighteou≈ønes, may froÃÑ heÃÑceforth not onely mortify our ≈øinful lu≈øtes & affections, but al≈øo bring forth ≈øuch frutes, as may be agreable to thy mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed wil, not for the worthines therof, but for y‚Ä¢ merites of thy dearely beloued ≈øonne Ie≈øus Chri≈øt our onely ≈øauiour, whom yu ha≈øt alredy geueÃÑ an oblatioÃÑ & offring for our ≈øinnes: & for who≈øe ≈øake, we are certeinly per≈øwaded, y‚Ä¢ thou wilt deny vs nothing, yt we ≈øhal a≈øke in his name, according to thy wil. For thy ≈øpirite doth a≈ø≈øure our con≈øcieÃÑces, that thou art our merciful father, & ≈øo loue≈øt vs thy childreÃÑ through him, that nothing is able to remoue thy heaueÃÑ ly grace & fauour froÃÑ vs: to the thee therfore (O father) with the ≈øonne and the holy gho≈øt be al honor & glory world without end. So be it.

div.head: ¬∂A Prayer to be ≈øaid before a man begin his worke.
div.p:
O Lord God mo≈øt merciful father & Sauiour, ≈øeyng it hath plea≈øed thee to coÃÑmauÃÑd vs to traueil, that we may releue our nede: we be≈øech thee of thy grace, ≈øo to ble≈ø≈øe our labour, yt thy ble≈ø≈øing may extend vnto vs, without the which we are not able to continue: & that this great fauor may be a witnes vnto vs of thy bountifulnes & a≈ø≈øi≈øtaÃÑce, ≈øo that therby we may know the fatherly care that yu ha≈øt ouer vs. Moreouer, O Lord, we be≈øech thee that thou woulde≈øt ≈øtrengtheÃÑ vs with thine holy ≈øpirit, that we may faithfully trauail in our e≈øtate and vocatioÃÑ without fraude or deceit: and that we may indeuour our ≈øelues to folow thine holy ordinauÃÑces, rather theÃÑ to ≈øeke to ≈øati≈øfy our gredy affectioÃÑs or de≈øire to gayne. And if it plea≈øe thee, O Lord, to pro≈øper our labour, geue vs a minde al≈øo to helpe theÃÑ that haue nede, according to that abilitie that, thou of thy mercy ≈øhalt geue vs: and knowing that al good thinges come of thee, graunt that we may humble our ≈øelues to our neyghbours, and not by any meanes lift our ≈øelues vp aboue them, whiche haue not receyued ≈øo liberal a portion as of thy mercy thou ha≈øt geuen vnto vs. And if it plea≈øe thee to trye and exerci≈øe vs by greater pouertye, and neede, then our fle≈øhe woulde de≈øire that thou woulde≈øt, yet, O Lorde, graunte vs grace to knowe
that thou wilt nouri≈øh vs coÃÑtinually through thy bouÃÑtiful liberality, that we be not ≈øo tempted that we fal into di≈øtru≈øt: but that we may paciently wayt til thou fil vs not onely wt corporal graces & benefites, but chiefly with thine heauenly and ≈øpiritual trea≈øures, to the intent that we may alwayes haue more ample occa≈øion to geue thee thaÃÑkes, and ≈øo wholy to re≈øt vpon thy mercyes. Heare vs, O Lord of mercy, through Ie≈øus Chri≈øt thy ≈øonne our Lord. Amen.

div.head: ¬∂A Prayer for the whole ≈øtate of Chri≈øtes Church.
div.p:
ALmighty God and mo≈øt merciful father, we huÃÑbly ≈øubmit our ≈øelues, and fal down before thy maie≈øty, be≈øeching thee from the botom of our hartes, that this ≈øede of thy worde now ≈øowen among≈øt vs, may take ≈øuch depe roote, that neither ye burning heat of per≈øecutioÃÑ cau≈øe it to wither, neither the thorny cares of this life do choke it, but that as ≈øede ≈øowen in good ground, it may bring forth thirty, ≈øixty, & an hundreth fold, as thy heauenly wi≈ødome hath appointed. And becau≈øe we haue nede continually to craue many things at thy haÃÑds, we huÃÑbly be≈øech thee (O heauenly father) to graunt vs thy holy ≈øpirit, to direct our petitioÃÑs, that they may procede from ≈øuch a feruent mind, as may be agreable to thy mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed wil. And ≈øeing that our infirmitie is able to doo nothing without thy helpe, & that thou art not ignoraunt with how many and great temptations, we poore wretches are on euery ≈øide enclo≈øed and compa≈ø≈øed: Let thy ≈øtrength, O Lord, ≈øu≈øtayne our weakenes, that we „Äà‚óä„Äâ defeÃÑ ded with the force of thy grace, may be ≈øafely per≈øerued agayn≈øt al a≈ø≈øaultes of Sathan: who goeth about coÃÑtinually like a roring Lion, ≈øeking to deuoure vs. Encrea≈øe our faith, O merciful father, that we do not ≈øwarue at any time from thy heauenly word: but augment in vs hope and loue, with a careful kepyng of al thy coÃÑmaundements: that no hardnes of hart, no Ipocri≈øie, no concupi≈øcence of the eyes, nor inticements of the world, do draw vs away froÃÑ thy obedience. And ≈øeing we liue now in the≈øe mo≈øt perilous times: let thy fatherly prouidence defend vs agayn≈øt the violence of al our enemyes, which do ≈øeke by almeanes to oppres thy truth. Furthermore for as much as by thy holy Apo≈øtle we be taught, to make our prayers & ≈øupplications for al men: We pray not onely for our ≈øelues here pre≈øent, but be≈øech thee al≈øo, to reduce al ≈øuch as be yet ignorauÃÑt, froÃÑ the mi≈øerable captiuitie of blindnes and errour, to the pure vnder≈øtanding, and knowledge of thy heauenly truth: that we al with one con≈øent & vnitie of minds, may wor≈øhip thee our onely God & ≈øauiour. And that al Pa≈øtors, ≈øhepe heardes and Mini≈øters, to whom thou ha≈øt committed the di≈øpen≈øation of thy holy word, and charge of thy cho≈øen people, may both in their life and
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ be found faithful, ≈øettyng onely before theyr eyes thy glory: and „Äà‚óä„Äâ by them al poore ≈øhepe, whiche wander and go a≈øtray, may be gathered & brought home to thy fold. Moreouer becau≈øe the harts of rulers are in thy handes, we be≈øech thee to direct, and gouerne the hartes of al kings, princes & maie≈øtrates, to whom thou ha≈øt committed the ≈øword: e≈øpecially (O Lord) accordyng to our bounden duty we be≈øech thee to mainteine & encrea≈øe the honorable e≈øtate of ye Queenes maie≈øtie, and al her mo≈øt noble coun≈øellers, and maie≈øtrates, and al the whole body of this coÃÑmune weale. Let thy fatherly fauor ≈øo pre≈øerue them, & thy holy ≈øpirite ≈øo gouerne their hartes, that they may in ≈øuch ≈øorte execute their office, that thy religion may be purely maintayned, maners reformed, and ≈øin puni≈øhed, according to the preci≈øe rule of thy holy word. And for that we be al members of the mi≈øtical body of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, we make our reque≈øtes vnto thee (O heauenly father) for al ≈øuch as are afflicted with any kind of cros or tribulation, as warre, plague, famine, ≈øicknes, pouertie, impri≈øonment, per≈øecution, bani≈øhment, or any other kinde of the rods, whether it be calamitie of body, or vexation of minde: that it would plea≈øe thee, to geue them patience and con≈øtancy, til thou ≈øend them ful deliueraunce of al theyr troubles. Roote out froÃÑ hence (O Lord) al rauening wolues, which, to fil theyr bellies, ≈øeke to de≈øtroy thy flocke. And ≈øhew thy great mercyes vpon tho≈øe our brethren in other couÃÑtreis, which are per≈øecuted, ca≈øt into pri≈øon, & daily coÃÑdeÃÑned to death for ye te≈øtimony of thy truth. And though they be vtterly de≈øtitute of al maÃÑs ayde, yet let thy ≈øwete comfort neuer depart from them: but ≈øo inflame their hartes with thy holy ≈øpirite, that they may boldly and cherefully abide ≈øuch trial, as thy godly wi≈øedome ≈øhal appoynt. So that at length as wel by theyr death, as by their life, the kingdoÃÑ of thy dere ≈øonne Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, may increa≈øe & ≈øhine through al the world. In who≈øe name we make our huÃÑble peticioÃÑs vnto thee as he hath taught vs. Our Father which art in heauen halowed by thy. &c.
